Description: Allied Waste Industries Inc. agreed to pay $125,000 as part of a civil settlement with the Department of Justice that resolved Allied's alleged violations of a 2000 consent decree entered in connection with Allied's acquisition of Browning-Ferris Industries Inc.

ALLTEL Corporation agreed to pay $1.325 million as part of a civil settlement with the Department of Justice and the state of Minnesota that resolved ALLTEL's alleged violations of two court orders entered in connection with ALLTEL's acquisition of Midwest Wireless Holdings LLC.

Company: Ameri-Source International Inc., Ameri-Source Specialty Products Inc. and Ameri-Source Holdings Inc.
Description: The Department of Justice announced that three importers and their owners -- Ameri-Source International Inc., Ameri-Source Specialty Products Inc., Ameri-Source Holdings Inc., Ajay Goel and Thomas Diener -- and a related importer, SMC Machining LLC, incorporated at Goel's direction and formerly owned by his wife, agreed to pay $3 million to resolve a lawsuit brought by the United States under the False Claims Act.  The lawsuit alleged that the defendants had engaged in a scheme to evade customs duties on imports of small-diameter graphite electrodes from the People's Republic of China.

The Department of Justice announced a settlement with American Airlines Inc. resolving the government's concerns regarding American's alleged violations of a 1994 consent decree. American agreed to pay a $3 million civil penalty, which included reimbursement to the government for its investigation.

American Electric Power, Inc. and AEP's wholly-owned subsidiary, AEP Energy Services, Inc. (AEPES) resolved an ongoing federal investigation into the submission of knowingly inaccurate reports by AEPES concerning a commodities market. AEPES agreed to pay a criminal penalty of $30 million.

Company: American Electric Power Company, Inc. and AEP Energy Services, Inc.
Description: American Electric Power and its subsidiary AEPES agreed to pay $30 million to resolve CFTC allegations that they repeatedly and deliberately reported false natural gas trading information, including price and volume information, to certain firms that compile natural gas price indexes. The complaint further alleged that AEP and AEPES knowingly delivered false information to price index compilers in an attempt to skew those indexes for their financial benefit.

AT&T Inc. agreed to pay more than $2 million as part of a civil settlement with the Department of Justice that resolved AT&T's alleged violations of two court orders entered in connection with its acquisition of Dobson Communications Corporation.

The U.S. Commodity Futures Trading Commission announced that BNP Paribas Commodity Futures, Ltd. would pay a $25,000 civil monetary penalty to settle charges that it failed to provide to the CFTC timely and accurate account information for a reportable large trader account, as required by CFTC regulations.
Chiquita Brands International Inc. pleaded guilty to one count of engaging in transactions with a terrorist organization in Colombia.

The U.S. Commodity Futures Trading Commission announced the issuance of an administrative order filing and simultaneously settling allegations against Cinergy Marketing & Trading, LP, as successor in interest to Cinergy Marketing & Trading, LLC. Cinergy agreed to pay a $3 million civil monetary penalty to settle charges of false reporting of trade information concerning natural gas transactions.

Citigroup Global Markets agreed to pay a $7 million penalty and admit wrongdoing to settle charges that a computer coding error caused the firm to provide the agency with incomplete blue sheet information about trades it executed.
A Japanese firm, CMET Inc., agreed to plead guilty and to pay a $100,000 criminal fine for conspiring to obstruct justice in connection with the settlement of a merger case.

The U.S. Commodity Futures Trading Commission issued an Order filing and settling charges against CNCGC Hong Kong Ltd., an investment and trading company headquartered in Hong Kong, for failing to file required CFTC Form 304 Cotton On-Call Reports, reporting its call cotton purchases and sales when it held or controlled at least one hundred (100) cotton futures positions, and for filing late Form 304 reports on two occasions.
The Securities and Exchange Commission charged Credit Suisse Securities (USA) LLC with submitting deficient information to the agency over a two-year period about trades done by its customers.

The U.S. Commodity Futures Trading Commission issued an Order filing and simultaneously settling charges against Deutsche Bank AG for failing to properly report its swaps transactions from in or about January 2013 until July 2015.

The Federal Housing Administration announced a settlement agreement with Equitable Trust Mortgage Corporation of Baltimore, Maryland, thereby terminating the suspension imposed on December 7, 2009. FHA suspended ETM's HUD/FHA approval because ETM allegedly  charged 37 borrowers for broker and loan origination fees in excess of what the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development allowed.

The Securities and Exchange Commission announced that Goldman, Sachs and one of its former investment bankers settled alleged pay-to-play violations involving undisclosed campaign contributions to then-Massachusetts state treasurer Timothy P. Cahill while he was a candidate for governor.

ITT Corporation, the leading manufacturer of military night vision equipment for the U.S. Armed Forces, admitted sending classified materials overseas and agreed to pay a $100 million criminal penalty, half of which was deferred.

Cal Dive International Inc. and its parent company Helix Energy Solutions Group Inc. agreed to pay $2 million as part of a civil settlement with the Department of Justice that resolved Cal Dive's alleged violations of a 2005 consent decree.

The U.S. Commodity Futures Trading Commission announced the filing and simultaneous settlement of charges against J.P. Morgan Futures, Inc., a registered futures commission merchant, for violating rules governing segregation of customer funds, timely computation of its segregation obligations, timely reporting of under-segregation deficiency to the CFTC and diligent supervision of its employees.

The U.S. Commodity Futures Trading Commission settled allegations that JPMorgan Ventures Energy Corp. and JPMorgan Chase Bank, N.A. failed to comply with their obligations to submit accurate large trader reports  for physical commodity swap positions.

The U.S. Commodity Futures Trading Commission issued an Order filing and settling charges that JPMorgan Chase Bank, N.A. failed to disclose certain conflicts of interest to clients of its U.S.-based wealth management business, J.P. Morgan Private Bank.

The U.S. Commodity Futures Trading Commission settled charges against J.P. Morgan Securities LLC for submitting inaccurate reports to the CFTC relating to the required reporting of positions held by certain large traders.

Company: Merrill Lynch Investment Managers, LLC and Merrill Lynch Alternative Investments, LLC

Description: The U.S. Commodity Futures Trading Commission settled charges against Mizuho Securities USA Inc. for failing to provide timely notice to the CFTC of secured fund deficiencies for failing to diligently supervise its employees.

Moody's Investors Service Inc., one of the largest credit ratings agencies in the United States, pleaded guilty and was sentenced to pay a $195,000 criminal fine for obstructing justice by destroying documents called for during an antitrust investigation.

Morgan Stanley & Co. agreed to pay $10 million to settle allegations that it failed to produce tens of thousands of e-mails during the SEC's IPO and Research Analyst investigations from Dec. 11, 2000, through at least July 2005.

The U.S. Commodity Futures Trading Commission announced the separate filings and simultaneous settlements of charges against Morgan Stanley Capital Group, Inc. and UBS Securities Inc. in connection with Morgan Stanley's alleged concealment from the New York Mercantile Exchange (NYMEX) the existence of a large Trade at Settlement (TAS) block crude oil trade. UBS Securities allegedly aided and abetted that concealment.

The Department of Justice announced that Wisconsin-based Novum Structures LLC  agreed to enter a guilty plea and pay $3 million to resolve its criminal and civil liability arising from its improper use of foreign materials on construction projects involving federal funds.  This use was in violation of contractual provisions implementing various domestic preference statutes, often referred to colloquially as the "Buy America" requirements.  Novum specializes in the design and construction of glass space frames often used in roofs and atrium enclosures.

OZ Management LP settled allegations that it provided inaccurate trade data to four prime brokers, causing inaccuracies in the brokers' books and records and in data provided to the SEC in investigations.  OZ Management, an investment adviser for numerous Och-Ziff funds, admitted wrongdoing and agreed to pay a $4.25 million penalty.

Republic Services Inc. agreed to pay a $1.5 million civil penalty as part of a settlement with the Department of Justice that resolved Republic's alleged violations of an existing 2000 consent decree in connection with an exchange of certain waste hauling and disposal assets by Republic and Allied Waste Industries Inc.

Rolex Watch U.S.A. Inc. agreed to pay $750,000 as part of a settlement with the Department of Justice that resolved Rolex's alleged violations of a 1960 consent decree that prohibited U.S. importers of Swiss watches and watch parts from engaging in anticompetitive practices in the U.S. watch industry.

Company: Russell Investments Ireland Limited and Russell Investments Cayman Ltd.

Description: A southern California freight company pleaded guilty and was sentenced to pay a $120,000 criminal fine for making false statements related to the Department of Defense's program to ship military household goods between Europe and the United States and between the United States mainland and Hawaii.

Company: Sage Partners LP & Sage Partners, LLC

Description: Scottrade agreed to pay $2.5 million to settle allegations of failing to provide the SEC with complete and accurate information about trades done by the firm and its customers, which is commonly called blue sheet data.

Company: State Street Bank and Trust Company
Description: State Street Bank and Trust Company agreed to pay $12 million to settle charges that it conducted a pay-to-play scheme through its then-senior vice president and a hired lobbyist to win contracts to service Ohio pension funds.

A Philadelphia-area private equity firm agreed to settle allegations that it violated pay-to-play rules by continuing to receive advisory fees from city and state pension funds following campaign contributions made by an associate in 2011 to the governor of Pennsylvania and a candidate for mayor of Philadelphia.

The U.S. Commodity Futures Trading Commission announced the separate filings and simultaneous settlements of charges against Morgan Stanley Capital Group, Inc. and UBS Securities Inc. in connection with Morgan Stanley's alleged concealment from the New York Mercantile Exchange (NYMEX) the existence of a large Trade at Settlement (TAS) block crude oil trade. UBS Securities allegedly aided and abetted that concealment.

The Department of Justice announced that University Furnishings LP and its general partner Freedom Furniture Group Inc. agreed to pay $15 million to resolve a lawsuit brought under the False Claims Act alleging that the companies made or conspired with others to make false statements to avoid paying duties on wooden bedroom furniture imported from the People's Republic of China.

Williams Power Company Inc. entered into an agreement with the government resolving an ongoing federal investigation into the submission of knowingly inaccurate reports by the company concerning a commodities market.  Williams Power was subsequently sold to a subsidiary of Bear Stearns, which later was acquired by JPMorgan Chase.

The Department of Justice announced that Z Gallerie LLC agreed to pay $15 million to resolve allegations that the company engaged in a scheme to evade customs duties on imports of wooden bedroom furniture from the People's Republic of China, in violation of the False Claims Act.  Z Gallerie sells upscale furniture and accessories in stores across the United States and through the Internet.

The Commodity Futures Trading Commission issued an Order filing and simultaneously settling charges against Morgan Stanley, a registered Futures Commission Merchant (FCM), for non-compliance with applicable rules governing Part 17 Large Trader reports to the CFTC spanning a ten-year period and affecting thousands of line items of information.

The U.S. Commodity Futures Trading Commission issued an Order filing and simultaneously settling charges against Citibank, N.A. and Citigroup Global Markets Limited for failing to report Legal Entity Identifier information for swap transactions properly to a Swap Data Repository (SDR), failing to establish the electronic systems and procedures necessary to do so, failing to correct errors in LEI data previously reported to an SDR, and failing to perform supervisory duties diligently with respect to LEI swap data reporting, all in violation of CFTC Regulations.

Agency: U.S. Attorney-Eastern District of North Carolina

Description: Carmen Group, a lobbying firm based in Washington, D.C.,  agreed to pay a civil penalty of $125,000 in order to resolve allegations that it repeatedly failed to file lobbying and contribution disclosure reports that are required by the Lobbying Disclosure Act.
Trafficking in counterfeit goods.

World Triathlon Corporation (Ironman) agreed to forfeit $2,761,910 to resolve allegations that it illegally charged athletes for a chance to win the opportunity to compete in the Ironman World Championship, held each October in Hawaii.

Extradition Transport of America settled  alleged violations of the Interstate Transportation of Dangerous Criminals Act of 2000 (also known as Jeanna's Act) relating to the October 2011 escape of Joseph M. Megna from ETA's custody at the Oriska Rest Area along Interstate 94 in North Dakota. This suit was the first ever filed under Jeanna's Act and sought restitution and civil penalties based on the escape of a prisoner froma private prisoner transport company.

Company: Livingstone Inc. dba Lee's Check Cashing
Description: A check cashing business in Kansas City, Kan., was fined $15,000 for failing to make currency transaction reports required by federal law.

TomorrowNow, Inc., a non-operating subsidiary of SAP, was sentenced to probation and ordered to pay a fine to the United States of $20 million for unauthorized access to computer servers belonging to Oracle Corporation and for willfully infringing copyrights held by Oracle.

Agency: U.S. Attorney-Southern District of New York
U.S. Attorney-Southern District of New York
U.S. Attorney-Southern District of New York
U.S. Attorney-Southern District of New York
U.S. Attorney-Western District of North Carolina

Description: NETeller PLC  -- an Internet payment business based in the Isle of Man --  admitted to criminal wrongdoing and agreed to forfeit $136,000,000 in criminal proceeds as part of an agreement to defer prosecution of NETeller for its participation in a conspiracy to promote Internet gambling businesses and to operate an unlicensed money transmitting business.
Agency: U.S. Attorney-Southern District of New York
U.S. Attorney-Southern District of New York
U.S. Attorney-Eastern District of North Carolina
U.S. Attorney-Western District of New York

Company: VMJ Construction, LLC  and Vigil Contracting, Inc.?
Description: VMJ Construction, LLC and its owner as well as Maryland-based Vigil Contracting, Inc. and its operations manager agreed to pay the United States $3.6 million to resolve allegations that they defrauded the Small Business Administration 8(a) Business Development Program.

Company: Cambridge Management, Inc., Jacksonville Elderly Tower I Limited Partnership, and Jacksonville Elderly Tower I GP, Inc.

Info Source: Attorney General Announces Settlement with a Wastewater Treatment Supplier Over Violations of PA Steel Products Procurement Act, States News Service, March 2, 2009 (via Nexis).

Company: Building Industry Association of Washington's Member Services Corporation

Description: Cafeno's Inc. pleaded guilty to charges of illegal gambling and filing a false tax return; $250,000 of its assets were ordered to be forfeited to the Commonwealth.
The California Attorney General announced that Capital Sweepstakes Systems, Inc. had agreed to pay $700,000 in civil penalties and costs and admit that it violated state gambling laws.
Citibank agreed to prevent its credit cards from being used to pay for illegal online gambling.

Commerce Park Housing Associates, a joint venture of Fish Commerce LLC and Messina Commerce LLC, agreed to pay $2.275 million in settlement of allegations it failed to comply with chapter 40B, the state's affordable housing law that requires developers who benefit from special provisions made for affordable housing developments to be limited to a reasonable profit from those projects.

Daymar College agreed to pay $1.2 million in restitution to students and to forgo collection of $11 million in debt owed by former students, in settlement of allegations it violated the Kentucky Consumer Protection Act by attempting to force students to buy textbooks from the more expensive college store, misrepresenting students' ability to transfer credits to other institutions, admitting students who failed admissions assessment, and hiring unqualified faculty staff.
Four Star Vending along with its owners were ordered to pay over $1 million when the owners pleaded guilty to illegal gaming and money laundering.
Failure to report association members that made contributions used to oppose a ballot initiative on genetically modified organisms, or GMOs.
Failure to report association members that made contributions used to oppose a ballot initiative on genetically modified organisms, or GMOs.

Agency: U.S. Attorney-Northern District of New York

Company: Master Builders Association of King and Snohomish Counties

Description: The Missouri Republican Party agreed to pay $182,675 ($122,675 suspended) to settle the alleged excess contributions it made to two candidates for state offices in violation of the Missouri campaign contribution limits.
National College was fined $147,000 for failing to comply with a subpoena issued by the Office of the Attorney General to provide information for an investigation of for-profit schools.

New England Internet Cafe and its owners pleaded guilty to charges of illegal gambling. As a condition of the plea, the judge ordered that 100 percent of NEIC's assets, over $100,000, be forfeited to the Commonwealth.

Pacific Surimi LLC, a seafood processing corporation with a plant in Warrenton, Oregon was found guilty on charges of theft in the first degree following the entry of a no contest in a case involving its purchases from Oregon fishermen.

Info Source: Attorney General Announces $429,000 Settlement from McKeesport Firm's Illegal Use of Foreign-Made Steel, Targeted News Service, December 23, 2013 (via Nexis).

Company: Service Employees International Union Leadership Council 14
United Keetoowah Band of Cherokee Indians

Info Source: Attorney General Martha Coakley Obtains Judgmen Against Online Weapons Retailer, States News Service, June 5, 2007 (via Nexis).

Description: A major Houston, Texas-based civil engineering company and its parent company agreed to enter into a three-year deferred prosecution agreement in connection with a criminal information charging the company with violating the Federal Election Campaign Act. As part of the agreement, Dannenbaum Engineering Corporation and its parent company Engineering Holding Corporation agreed to pay a $1.6 million criminal fine for its involvement in a multi-year conduit contribution scheme.

Agency: U.S. Attorney-Southern District of New York

Description: All Vision agreed to pay $2.85 million to settle allegations that the company made false statements and improperly withheld money owed to the United States Postal Service in connection with the company's marketing and management of various commercial outdoor advertising licenses.

Agency: U.S. Attorney-Southern District of New York

Company: Holy Land Foundation For Relief and Development

Agency: U.S. Attorney-Southern District of New York

Company: Mantra Films Inc. and MRA Holdings Inc.
Description: Mantra Films pleaded guilty; MRS Holdings received a deferred prosecution agreement.

The Los Angeles City Attorney secured a $1.8 million settlement from an advertising agency in a case surrounding a dispute over more than a dozen supergraphics and 500-plus poster-sized signs around the city.
Info Source: Judge Approves $1.8M Settlement With Billboard Company, City News Service, August 10, 2011 (via Nexis).

Description: Clear Channel Outdoor agreed to pay $30,000 in fines for failing to properly disclose its role in providing billboards touting candidates.
Info Source: Billboard Firm to Be Fined for Political Effort; Clear Channel Outdoor agrees to pay $30,000 for not disclosing that it independently backed Rocky Delgadillo and other L.A. candidates, Los Angeles Times, October 6, 2005 (via Nexis).

Description: Youbet.com agreed to pay over $1.3 million in settlement of allegations it violated state laws against unfair competition and false advertising by offering illegal computer-based off-track betting.

Info Source: City Receives Record $1.1 Million Settlement Payment Over Owners' Failure to Maintain Landmarked Windmere Apartment Complex on Manhattan's Upper West Side, US State News, May 23, 2009 (via Nexis).

Description: Two bioscience companies reached a $7.8 million settlement with the Orange County District Attorney's office over allegations that they illegally sold fetal tissue to companies around the world.
Info Source: CITY & STATE; Firms accused in fetal tissue sales suit settle, Los Angeles Times, December 11, 2017 (via Nexis).

Company: Northpark SD LLC and SD Observatory, LLC
Description: Northpark SD and SD Observatory, operators of the Observatory North Park concert venue, agreed to pay $140,000 in settlement of allegations they maintained a public nuisance and operated without required permits.
1735 Garnet, LLC and its owner were ordered to pay $200,000 civil penalties stemming from allegations it allowed a marijuana dispensary to lease property in violation of zoning laws.
North County Holistic, Inc. was ordered to pay $600,000 to resolve allegations it operated a marijuana dispensary that was in violation of local zoning laws.
SoCal Holistic Health, Inc. was ordered to pay civil penalties for operating a pot shop in violation of City zoning laws.

Company: The Nobel Family Trust and the Abeles Family Trust
Description: The Nobel Family Trust and the Abeles Family Trust were ordered to pay a total of $120,000 in civil penalties and $1,800 in costs for violating zoning laws by leasing property to a marijuana dispensary.

Company: Town & Country Resort Hotel and Convention Center
Description: A hotel in Mission Valley agreed to pay fines, make repairs and donate an open-space easement along the San Diego River to make amends for what regulators said was a parking lot constructed illegally next to the waterway in late 2005.
Info Source: Hotel will pay fines for work by river; Town & Country parking lot at issue, San Diego Union-Tribune, April 8, 2007 (via Nexis).
Operator of football game will pay fines; Group pleads guilty to filing false claim, San Diego Union-Tribune, July 21, 2006 (via Nexis).
Cheetahs agrees to pay $15,000 to city to settle illegal-sign suit, San Diego Union-Tribune, March 9, 2004 (via Nexis).

Description: Lexamark Building, LLC agreed to pay $600,000 in settlement of allegations it rented the basement of a laundromat to multiple tenants without permits and in conditions that violated multiple public health and safety laws.

Academy of Art University agreed to pay an estimated $60 million ($20 million in penalties and fees, and units of affordable housing valued at $40 million) in settlement of allegations it had ignored city land use rules, with multiple violations for violations of zoning, signage, environmental, historical preservation and building code requirements.

Company: Tobacco Plaza Center Smoke & Gift Shop

Info Source: Contractors gave cash illegally; Group pleads guilty in Democrat donation case, says it didn't grasp ban, Austin American-Statesman, October 28, 2005 (via Nexis).

Description: The Department of Financial Services fined SN Servicing Corp., a New York State-registered mortgage loan servicer, $100,000 for failing to maintain two properties in Gloversville, N.Y., under New York's Abandoned Property Relief Act, which requires banks and mortgage services to fulfill certain maintenance obligations at so-called zombie properties.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Description: The Department of Financial Services fined PHH Mortgage Corp. $119,000 for failing to maintain a vacant an abandoned property under DFS's Vacant and Abandoned Property Law, which requires banks and mortgage servicers to fulfill certain maintenance obligations at so-called zombie properties.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Info Source: U.S. Reaches Settlements with Two Arizona Businesses for Failing to Pay Proper Postage, US Fed News, June 18, 2009 (via Nexis).
U.S. Reaches Settlements with Two Arizona Businesses for Failing to Pay Proper Postage, US Fed News, June 18, 2009 (via Nexis).
WETHERSFIELD COMPANY THAT MADE ILLEGAL FEDERAL CAMPAIGN CONTRIBUTIONS IS SENTENCED, US Fed News, May 4, 2005 (via Nexis).
AMUSEMENT GAMES SUPPLY COMPANY PLEADS GUILTY TO MONEY LAUNDERING, US Fed News, May 9, 2007 (via Nexis).
ASPHALT COMPANY CONVICTED OF FALSE STATEMENTS; ORDERED TO PAY $168,000 FINE, US Fed News, April 15, 2005 (via Nexis).
ENGLISH CONSTRUCTION COMPANY PAYS $2.5 MILLION FOR MAKING FALSE STATEMENTS, US Fed News, March 5, 2007 (via Nexis).

Agency: U.S. Attorney-Southern District of West Virginia
